name: Kundalini Yoga
summary: A spiritual and therapeutic yoga tradition combining postures, breathwork, mantra chanting, and meditation aimed at awakening inner energy (kundalini) and promoting physical, mental, and spiritual well-being.
description: Kundalini Yoga is a dynamic style of yoga that integrates physical postures (asanas), breathing techniques (pranayama), mantra chanting, hand gestures (mudras), and meditation. Rooted in Tantric and Sikh traditions, it emphasizes awakening kundalini energy, conceptualized as a dormant spiritual force at the base of the spine. Practices are structured in 'kriyas'—set sequences designed for specific outcomes (e.g., stress relief, detoxification, emotional balance). In modern health settings, Kundalini Yoga has been studied for its benefits in stress reduction, anxiety, depression, PTSD, and substance use recovery. It is typically practiced in group classes led by certified instructors and includes both physical exertion and deep meditative elements.

treatment_variants: Breathwork practices (e.g., Breath of Fire, alternate nostril breathing)
Relaxation with gong or sound bath
treatment_duration: Chronic conditions: ongoing practice over weeks to months
metadata.training_required: Certified Kundalini Yoga instructors (commonly through Yoga Alliance–recognized programs or specific kundalini schools).
metadata.regulatory_status: Unregulated practice; certification is voluntary through yoga organizations.

contraindications: Relative: Cardiovascular disease (certain breathwork techniques), pregnancy (avoid specific kriyas or intense breath practices).
clinical_metadata.safety_profile: Generally safe when taught by trained instructors; risks include dizziness, hyperventilation, or emotional overwhelm. Traumatic material can surface during deep practices, requiring trauma-informed support.
clinical_metadata.evidence_level: Moderate. Emerging evidence supports benefit for anxiety, depression, PTSD, and substance use recovery; further rigorous trials are needed.

sections.text: Kundalini Yoga combines physical exertion, controlled breathing, and mantra chanting to activate both parasympathetic relaxation responses and sympathetic arousal in a balanced sequence. Physiologically, breath of fire and rhythmic movements modulate vagal tone, heart rate variability, and stress hormones. Meditation and chanting may influence attention networks, emotional regulation, and neuroplasticity. Symbolically, it is described as awakening 'kundalini energy' rising through chakras to support spiritual and psychological integration.

sections.preparation: Comfortable clothing, yoga mat, water, optional head covering (traditional). Screen participants for medical/psychiatric contraindications.
procedure: Tuning in with mantra (e.g., Ong Namo Guru Dev Namo).
Practice of a kriya: a structured sequence of postures, breathwork, mudras, and mantra repetition.
Deep relaxation (often with gong or sound).
sections.frequency: Can be practiced daily or several times per week.
sections.duration: 60–90 minutes typical class; shorter home practices possible.
sections.total_treatment_time: Benefits often appear within weeks; sustained practice enhances outcomes.
